media_camera Brandon and Theo Boland, both 11, say they have been left behind by crammed school buses. Pictures: John Appleyard Wentworth Courier Extra buses to be provided after parents complained children were arriving to school late Kate Bastians, Wentworth Courier February 21, 2017 3:51pm Power pole in man’s driveway
EXTRA buses will be provided to take Rose Bay Secondary College students to and from school after parents complained their children were arriving to school late because they could not fit onto crammed buses.
Brandon Boland, who catches the bus from Bronte, said he had not made it onto the 717 bus to school seven times and the 713 bus home three times because it was too full.
Brandon, 11, said their dad had to drive them to school last Thursday and another student's mum had to take them last Monday and Wednesday.
“On my second day of school I was told to get off the bus because it was too full and I was panicking because I got separated from everyone,” he said.
media_camera Brandon and Theo made it onto the 717 on Friday morning but they were packed in like sardines. It was only the second time last week they made it onto the bus.
He had to catch the 711 to Bondi Junction, then the 360 to Birrell St and then walk about 500 metres to his house.
“I was dreading the walk because it was a really hot day and our bags are really heavy.”
His mother Lily Boland said that was further than she allowed her sons to walk on busy roads.
“They are only 11,” she said.
“It’s the first time they have had to catch public transport so it’s already overwhelming for them and even more daunting if they are left behind.”
Father Berrick Boland said he saw several students from the College “walking the streets” last Thursday when he drove the boys to school.
“You can’t leave kids stranded like that, it’s ridiculous,” he said.
media_camera Year 11 student Ali Rudkin says she is often late to school because they buses are too full. Picture: John Appleyard
Year 11 student Ali Rudkin had to get on the 8.53 bus on Friday — leaving her just seven minutes to get to school — after the earlier bus did not stop for her and three other students on Bondi Rd because it was packed like sardines.
“It happens often now since a record number of year seven students started year seven this year so now the buses are always full,” she said.
“I get to school late a lot.”
ARE SELF-SERVE CHECK-OUTS TURNING AUSSIES INTO ‘SWIPERS’? Are self-serve checkouts turning Aussies into 'SWIPERS'? 1:43 Opinions on self-serve checkouts are dividing customers and supermarket chains, with 9 per cent of Aussies admitting to using the technology to steal items
February 21st 2017 9 hours ago /video/video.news.com.au/News/ Are self-serve check-outs turning Aussies into 'SWIPERS'? College principal Richard Skinner said he had received a call on Monday afternoon from Sydney Buses informing him an extra 717 bus would be provided in the morning and also an extra bus in the afternoon from March 13.
Mr Skinner said parents had been “absolutely right” to raise the issue but he was “hopeful” the extra buses would fix the problem.
“We will continue to monitor the situation,” he said.
